days.title: Entrance: build a daily form for these 30 days
days.learn: This app is for building a daily loop before collecting more knowledge. In the morning, align body, speech, and mind briefly. At night, align and close. If you break, returning is enough.
days.example: Today, do not aim for perfect. Create just one aligned moment.

actionOptions.text: In the morning, straighten your back and bow once (10 seconds)
In the morning, say a short vow once (silently is OK)
In the morning, return to your breath for 1 minute

days.nightQuestion: Which was most disturbed today: body, speech, or mind?

days.title: Body: posture is the shortest alignment
days.learn: The entry to aligning the body is posture and movement. Simply straightening your back calms a hurried mind. First, increase the times you notice and return.
days.example: If your posture collapses the moment you see a notification, that is your practice spot.

actionOptions.text: Before replying, straighten your back once
Before speaking, close your mouth and take one breath
When you notice haste, lower your gaze and take one breath

days.nightQuestion: When your posture collapsed, was your mind also rushing?

days.title: Speech: words are easily thrown off by momentum
days.learn: Speech is easiest to disturb when momentum builds. Keep it short and careful. Rather than fixing words after, align by taking one breath before you speak.
days.example: Strong words often come with speed.

actionOptions.text: Take one breath before speaking
If you speak too fast, relax your shoulders once
If you get irritated, label it in your mind: hot

days.nightQuestion: Was there a moment you almost said an extra word today?

days.title: Mind: scattering is natural, returning is practice
days.learn: The mind naturally scatters. What matters is not never scattering, but how many times you notice and return. Alignment begins the moment you return.
days.example: Even if you scatter 10 times in one minute, returning 10 times is a successful practice.

actionOptions.text: Return to the breath for 1 minute (scattering is OK)
Lower your gaze and tuck your chin (10 seconds)
Say calm down once in your mind

days.nightQuestion: Could you count the times you returned rather than the times you scattered?

days.title: Three Mysteries: it is enough to align briefly
days.learn: The Three Mysteries are explained as doing body, speech, and mind together. At first, prioritize alignment over length. Even 10 seconds each creates an axis for the day.
days.example: On difficult days, body alone is OK. Align again tomorrow.

actionOptions.text: Body -> Speech -> Mind, 10 seconds each (30 seconds total)
Say a short vow once, slowly
Return to the breath just 3 times

days.nightQuestion: Which of body, speech, or mind helped you most today?

days.title: Alignment begins the moment you notice
days.learn: Rather than making disturbance zero, notice sooner. When you notice, insert just one alignment (posture, one breath, or stopping words). That is enough.
days.example: The moment you notice is the shortest entrance to practice.

actionOptions.text: Bow once at the moment of disturbance (silently if needed)
If strong words are about to come out, be silent once
Notice and take one breath: I am disturbed

days.nightQuestion: Was there a moment you noticed disturbance early?

days.title: Week review: do not blame imbalance, cultivate it
days.learn: Look at imbalance in body, speech, and mind over the week. Imbalance is not a flaw but a marker of what to cultivate. Next week, care for just one weak area.
days.example: Do not fix everything. Be one step more careful.

actionOptions.text: Pick one weak area and set it as tomorrow's vow
Decide: in the morning, I will align posture
Decide: today I will keep words shorter

days.nightQuestion: Next week, which of body, speech, or mind will you treat one step more carefully?

days.title: Night form: align and close (entry)
days.learn: At night, align and close. In this app, close briefly in the order repentance -> vow -> dedication. Today, repentance alone is enough.
days.example: When night is aligned, the next morning feels lighter.

actionOptions.text: At night, choose one repentance (body/speech/mind)
Say I am sorry once in your mind
Release your shoulders before sleep (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: Which was most disturbed today: body, speech, or mind?

days.title: Repentance: not to blame, but to align
days.learn: Repentance is not to blame yourself, but an entrance to notice disturbance and align. I am sorry is sometimes introduced as a heart of reflection.
days.example: If you enter a blame loop, return to something small.

actionOptions.text: Say I am sorry in your mind once, then take one breath
If you went too far, rephrase briefly once
Tuck your chin and lower your gaze (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: Did blame appear? If so, could you return briefly?

days.title: Vow: decide just one thing for tomorrow
days.learn: A vow is deciding just one alignment for tomorrow. Do not make it big. Keep it short and concrete. The smaller it is, the longer it lasts.
days.example: One minute every day beats thirty minutes every day.

actionOptions.text: Tomorrow, straighten your back once before replying
Tomorrow, take one breath before speaking
Tomorrow, return to the breath for 1 minute

days.nightQuestion: Is tomorrow's vow too heavy? Is it just one thing?

days.title: Dedication: do not close only for yourself
days.learn: Dedication is a form of closing that does not end inside yourself, but remembers someone. It does not need to be big. One person is enough.
days.example: Simply thinking of someone can soften your words.

actionOptions.text: Dedicate: think of family and say may you sleep well once
Dedicate: think of your team and take one breath
Dedicate: bow once and close (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: Who do you want to dedicate to today? (self, family, team, everyone)

days.title: Speech: cultivate the power to stop
days.learn: Speech is easily disturbed by speed. Stopping is a strong practice. The more times you can stop, the more your words align.
days.example: Stopping is not losing. It is winning alignment.

actionOptions.text: If you notice fast speech, stop once
After stopping, take one breath
After stopping, drop your shoulders (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: How many times did you stop? Even zero is OK if you noticed.

days.title: Mind: know the signs of haste
days.learn: Disturbance of mind increases with haste. If you can notice the signs (fast speech, raised gaze, lifted shoulders), you can insert alignment.
days.example: Noticing the signs means you have a signal to return.

actionOptions.text: When you notice haste, take one breath
Lower your shoulders (10 seconds)
Say it is OK once in your mind

days.nightQuestion: What was your sign of haste? (body, words, mind)

days.title: Week review: a day you returned matters most
days.learn: Continuity is about returning, not streaks. Even if you miss days, returning is practice. Even doing only the night form is enough.
days.example: Starting again is the most precious act.

actionOptions.text: Do the night form (repentance -> vow -> dedication) in 45 seconds
On hard days, just bow once
On hard days, say see you tomorrow once

days.nightQuestion: What one phrase helped you return?

days.title: Learning to action: do not end with knowledge
days.learn: Translate learning into today's action. When it lands in action, understanding stays in the body.
days.example: If more learning makes you scatter, make the action smaller.

actionOptions.text: Choose one action for today and do it
Say today only this and keep it short
If you hesitate, take one breath before choosing

days.nightQuestion: Did it land in action? What changed when it did?

days.title: Body: environment is part of the body
days.learn: Body is not only posture but also your workspace. Tidying your desk for one minute makes the mind scatter less.
days.example: A cluttered desk often equals a cluttered mind.

actionOptions.text: Before work, tidy your desk for 1 minute
Count three breaths while tidying
Say I will align now once

days.nightQuestion: How did your focus change before and after tidying?

days.title: Speech: short, clean, only what is needed
days.learn: Speech practice can be done by reducing words. Short words reduce disturbance.
days.example: When you want to add one more line in a meeting, that is the practice spot.

actionOptions.text: Reduce one word in conversation
Take one breath before reducing
Before speaking, straighten your back (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: What happened when you reduced words?

days.title: Mind: do not push away, watch
days.learn: When aligning mind, do not push away thoughts. Notice and return. Simply labeling it as thought creates distance.
days.example: If pushing away makes it stronger, watching is shorter.

actionOptions.text: When a thought appears, label it in your mind: thought
After labeling, drop your shoulders (10 seconds)
After labeling, say ok once

days.nightQuestion: Did labeling create a little distance?

days.title: Three Mysteries: if simultaneous is hard, use order
days.learn: The Three Mysteries are explained as done together, but beginners can use order. If you cycle body -> speech -> mind briefly, the sense of alignment grows.
days.example: If you freeze trying to do all at once, order wins.

actionOptions.text: Body -> Speech -> Mind, 30 seconds each (90 seconds total)
Do only the speech part carefully (10 seconds)
Do only the mind part for 1 minute

days.nightQuestion: Did choosing an order reduce hesitation?

days.title: Daily Five Hearts: say thank you carefully
days.learn: The Daily Five Hearts are introduced as daily attitudes and sometimes linked to the Three Mysteries and Three Actions. Today, say thank you carefully.
days.example: A careful single phrase is the shortest practice for aligning speech.

actionOptions.text: Say thank you carefully once
Before speaking, take one breath to think of the other person
When speaking, give a small bow once

days.nightQuestion: When you said it carefully, how did your mind move?

days.title: Week review: reproduce the aligned moment
days.learn: Remember one aligned moment this week. Next time you are disturbed, reproduce that posture and breath. That becomes practice.
days.example: If you can reproduce it, alignment is no longer luck.

actionOptions.text: Reproduce the posture of an aligned moment for 10 seconds
Recall the speed of the breath from that moment
Say the short phrase from that moment once

days.nightQuestion: Could you recall one aligned moment?

days.title: Ajikan: 3 minutes is enough
days.learn: Ajikan is introduced as an important Shingon meditation. Do not aim for special experiences. Just posture -> breath -> quiet gaze for 3 minutes.
days.example: The courage to end at 3 minutes protects continuity.

actionOptions.text: 3 minutes: posture -> breath (scattering is OK)
Straighten your back and tuck your chin (10 seconds)
Before starting, say quiet once

days.nightQuestion: Was 3 minutes enough? Did you want more?

days.title: Ajikan: count return moments
days.learn: Scattering is natural. Returning is practice. Today, quietly count the times you returned. If you can count, that is enough.
days.example: Counting is not evaluation; it supports awareness.

actionOptions.text: Count the times you returned in 3 minutes
Each time you scatter, release your shoulders
After finishing, say good once

days.nightQuestion: Could you count without blaming yourself?

days.title: Ajikan: steady form over specialness
days.learn: Ajikan is about continuing a steady form rather than chasing special experiences. Try doing it at the same time (fixed time is strongest).
days.example: When time is fixed, you rely less on motivation.

actionOptions.text: Do 3 minutes at the same time each day (morning or night)
Fix the place you sit
Fix a short start cue phrase

days.nightQuestion: Did fixing the time reduce hesitation?

days.title: Speech to mind: a short vow aligns the heart
days.learn: When speech aligns, mind aligns more easily. Today, choose one short vow. Keep it short and light.
days.example: Short vows like be careful last longer.

actionOptions.text: Say one short vow once (e.g., be careful)
After the vow, take one breath
After the vow, straighten your back (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: Did your vow stay light and short?

days.title: Body to mind: when the body collapses, the mind scatters
days.learn: When the body collapses, the mind scatters. Today, increase the number of times you reset. Each reset deepens alignment.
days.example: Being able to return is stronger than never collapsing.

actionOptions.text: Straighten your spine three times in a day
Each time you reset, take one breath
Each time you reset, say right here in your mind once

days.nightQuestion: How did your mood change when you reset?

days.title: Night form: close in 45 seconds (complete)
days.learn: Night is a three-part set: repentance, vow, dedication. Do all three in 45 seconds today. If you can close briefly, it is a success.
days.example: Closing the night changes how you enter the next morning.

actionOptions.text: Choose repentance (body/speech/mind)
Choose vow (body/speech/mind)
Choose dedication (self/family/team/everyone)

days.nightQuestion: Did having a form reduce hesitation?

days.title: Less learning lasts longer
days.learn: The more learning you add, the more you scatter. For continuity, less learning is enough. Read just one card today. That is a win.
days.example: Not enough means room to grow. Add more in the next 30 days.

actionOptions.text: Read only one learning card (do not dive deep)
After reading, bow once (10 seconds)
Say today is enough once

days.nightQuestion: Did you want to add more? (that is a good sign)

days.title: Next month: cultivate one weak area
days.learn: Choose one weak area among body, speech, and mind and cultivate it. It is not a flaw, it is next month's theme. Set it as tomorrow's vow today.
days.example: Being careful with just one thing is how you win long term.

actionOptions.text: Choose one weak area (body/speech/mind)
Declare it with a short phrase once
After declaring, bow once (10 seconds)

days.nightQuestion: Could you choose one weak area without blaming yourself?

days.title: Closing: thin and long (your minimal routine)
days.learn: Thirty days is the entrance. From here, keep it thin and long. Decide your minimal routine to continue (morning is body only, night is form only, both are OK).
days.example: If you can reduce it to something you can keep, you win.

actionOptions.text: Define your minimal routine in one line
Allow yourself to do only a morning bow
Allow yourself to close with see you tomorrow only

days.nightQuestion: What will you discard to keep going?
